message.content:
<<<api>>>: Enhanced for loop in Java
<<<code>>>: int[] array = {1, 2, 3...};
StringBuilder builder = new StringBuilder();
int i = 0;
for(int num : array){
    builder.append("" + num);
    if(i != array.length - 1){
        builder.append(",");
    }
    i++;
}
<<<explanation>>>: You can use an external counter to keep track of the current iteration. By comparing the counter with the length of the array minus 1, you can determine if it is the last iteration and avoid appending the comma.

<<<api>>>: Enhanced for loop in Java
<<<code>>>: int[] array = {1, 2, 3...};
StringBuilder builder = new StringBuilder();
int count = 0;
for(int i : array){
    count++;
    builder.append("" + i);
    if(count != array.length)
        builder.append(",");
}
<<<explanation>>>: You can use a counter variable to keep track of the current iteration. By comparing the count with the length of the array, you can determine if it is the last iteration and avoid appending the comma.

<<<api>>>: Enhanced for loop
<<<code>>>: int[] array = {1, 2, 3...};
StringBuilder builder = new StringBuilder();
int index = 0;
for(int i : array){
    builder.append("" + i);
    if(index < array.length - 1)
        builder.append(",");
    index++;
}
<<<explanation>>>: You can use an external counter to keep track of the index of the current iteration. By comparing the index with the length of the array minus 1, you can determine if it is the last iteration and avoid appending the comma.

<<<code>>>: int[] array = {1, 2, 3...};

<<<api>>>: Enhanced for loop
<<<code>>>: int[] array = {1, 2, 3...};
StringBuilder builder = new StringBuilder();
int counter = 0;
for(int i : array){
    counter++;
    builder.append("" + i);
    if(counter != array.length)
        builder.append(",");
}
<<<explanation>>>: You can use a counter variable to keep track of the current iteration. Check if the counter is equal to the length of the array to determine if it is the last iteration. If it is not the last iteration, append the comma.

<<<api>>>: enhanced for loop
<<<code>>>: int[] array = {1, 2, 3...};
StringBuilder builder = new StringBuilder();
int counter = 0;
for(int i : array){
    builder.append("" + i);
    counter++;
    if(counter < array.length){
        builder.append(",");
    }
}
<<<explanation>>>: You can use an external counter to keep track of the current iteration. By comparing the counter with the length of the array, you can determine if it is the last iteration and avoid appending the comma.

<<<api>>>: Enhanced for loop
<<<code>>>: int[] array = {1, 2, 3...};
StringBuilder builder = new StringBuilder();
int counter = 0;
for(int i : array){
    builder.append("" + i);
    if(counter != array.length - 1)
        builder.append(",");
    counter++;
}
<<<explanation>>>: You can use an external counter to keep track of the current iteration. By comparing the counter with the length of the array minus 1, you can determine if it is the last iteration and avoid appending the comma.

<<<api>>>: Iterator.hasNext
<<<code>>>: int[] array = {1, 2, 3...};
StringBuilder builder = new StringBuilder();
Iterator<Integer> iterator = Arrays.stream(array).iterator();
while(iterator.hasNext()){
    int i = iterator.next();
    builder.append("" + i);
    if(iterator.hasNext()){
        builder.append(",");
    }
}
<<<explanation>>>: You can use the Iterator.hasNext() method to check if there is a next element in the iteration. If there is a next element, you can append the comma, otherwise, you don't append the comma.

<<<api>>>: Enhanced for loop
<<<code>>>: int[] array = {1, 2, 3...};
StringBuilder builder = new StringBuilder();
int counter = 0;
for(int i : array){
  counter++;
  builder.append("" + i);
  if(counter != array.length)
    builder.append(",");
}
<<<explanation>>>: You can use a counter variable to keep track of the current iteration. By comparing the counter with the length of the array, you can determine if it is the last iteration and avoid appending the comma.
